intro: Robinia × ambigua, commonly known as the false acacia or yellowwood, is a hybrid deciduous shrub or small tree native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are pinnately arranged and have a distinctive yellowish-green color. The plant produces fragrant, pale yellow to cream-colored flowers in late spring, which are clustered in racemes. Its bark is thick, flaky, and often has a reddish-brown appearance. Robinia × ambigua is adapted to a variety of soil types and is often found in woodland edges and disturbed sites.
